conclusion: Separation between objects equals the difference in distances covered.
Distance traveled is the area under the velocity curve.
Separation equals the vertical area gap between the two curves.
From origin to t1, object A is faster than object B.
Area under A's curve grows more quickly than B's from origin to t1.
Between t1 and t2, speeds of A and B cross.
After t1, object B is always faster than object A.
B's area starts catching up with and eventually overtaking A's.
Distance difference starts at zero at t=0, increases while A is faster, and keeps increasing until B makes up the extra area.
Area gap stops growing and begins to shrink when B's area becomes larger than A's.
Graph shows equal-area crossover at t2.
Distance between objects reaches maximum at t=t2.
After t2, the gap diminishes, becoming zero again at t4.
